captions.text:
Back in the 1690s there were only two countries
on the island of Great Britain: The Kingdom
of Scotland and the Kingdom of England.

England and the other great european powers
were doing rather well for themselves by expanding
their empires through the cunning use of flags.

Scotland had no empire but wanted to join
in the game, and thus needed to establish
a colony of her very own.
But where to build it?
"Panama!" declared Scotland.

She imagined the colony's strategic location
would make trade with the far east safer and

faster by eliminating the long journey around
the hazardous Cape of Good Hope and Cape Horn

where both wind and wave delight in smashing
ships against rock and ice.

"Who will lend me money to make this great
idea a reality?" asked Scotland.
No one, was the answer.

Instead of helping, the european empires started
trade wars with Scotland to limit the power
of their future rival.

So, poor Scotland had to fund the project
herself. She gathered up all the money she

could, literally put it all in a big box and,
capital thusly raised, sent off a colonial
ship.

400,000 pounds, 8,000 kilometers and 111 days
later, 2,500 Scotsmen landed on the shores

of Panama, named it 'New Caledonia' and immediately
discovered a few small problems with their
plan:

First, the mountains on the western side of
Panama were a wee bit larger than expected,

making overland trade pretty much impossible.
Even if they had thought of building a canal,

the technology to do so was still 200 years
away.

Second, The woolen goods brought to trade
with the locals was useless in the endless
heat and humidity.

Third, the Spanish Conquistadors had already
planted flags on the sandy beaches and weren't
too happy to see the scots arrive.

And fourth, without adequate supplies, disease
such as the perennial tropical favorite, Dysentery,
spread quickly.

Two years and 2,000 dead scots later, they
abandoned the project.

Now, this wasn't the first failed attempt
at Scottish empire -- early colonies had been

tried and abandoned in Nova Scotia, New Jersey
and Carolina, but the Panama debacle was particularly
devastating to Scotland because she was over-invested.

Remember that money-in-a-box? Turns out it
was a fifth of the wealth of the whole country.
Oops.

Scotland's sudden impoverishment proved a
golden opportunity for The Kingdom of England

who was growing increasingly worried that
her neighbor to the North would ally with
an enemy.

England offered Scotland a deal that would
reimburse Scotland for her losses if she voted

for union. In 1707 Scotland agreed and the
Kingdom of Great Britain was born.

While the surrender of independence was unpopular
in Scotland, her economy improved with access

to once English (now British) trade routes
and she played a formative role in what would
soon be the largest empire in human history.

That being said, still more than 300 years
later, Scotland has never fully given up her
national identity and thoughts of independence.

comments.text:
+Alan McEwing I got caught up in the moment with classifying BAE systems as 
an English Company ;p, when your correct. It is a British Company, as it 
operates all over Britain, but atleast you got the message I was trying to 
imply. The rest of the companies I was correct.  Accuracy International and 
Webley & Scott are local companies within England that are not operated 
anywhere else in the UK, thus should they be classified as 
producing 'English Firearms' . The same for Rolls Royce, Jaguar, Land 
Rover, Bentley, etc, etc. Those are 'English cars' as they are companies 
within England that are not produced anywhere else in the UK. They have 
nothing to do with Scotland, Wales, or Northern Ireland... and even though 
the English Parliament was disbanded in 1707. It doesn't make the British 
Parliament as mother of all Parliaments, as many people see to think of it 
that way. And I do think it would be fair to change the name of the 'Bank 
of England' to the 'Bank of Britain or UK'. As it's the bank of the rest of 
the UK as well. But my overall message, was to enlighten you a bit, if you 
didn't already know, that so much of what is 'English' gets subsumed into 
what is 'British'.
comments.author: January January

comments.text:
+January January. Just as many foreigners call the BBC "home counties" 
accent an English accent as a British one.I speak English abroad and the 
first thing I get asked about 95% of the time is are you English? Why 
should it not be "are you British"? 


Particularly strange choice to call BAE an English company. Does BAE 
Systems not build British ships for the Royal Navy on the Clyde with a fair 
amount of local workers, and planes for the RAF flown by British pilots.Its 
seems strange in particular you want to attribute that company to be 
English.By extension is it the English army or the English navy or the 
English airforce? The company has decided to name itself "British" but you 
think it is cultural oppression of the English? And how does this British 
state carry out this oppression.You have about 90 % of the population.So it 
is yourselves oppressing yourselves.Or is it finally 300 years too late 
suddenly getting it right,recognising the sovereign state is the UK of GB 
and NI and hence it should be primarily things are British unless there is 
good reason to the contrary? It never happened till recently hence the 
reactionary clinging to the Scottish and Welsh (and Irish) identities from 
the smaller nations.We seem to have done it too well for your liking!


You have a fair point about some other companies you listed. Companies 
producing quintessentially local product should indeed be called English. 
In the same way it is Scottish or Irish whisky companies it should be say 
English Cider companies or Cornish pasty makers. The cars well arguable but 
you have a point. In fairness there are companies that get called Scottish 
I would equally say were British and there is no reason to really do so.


Parliament. Yeah I would agree I think it is the English Parliament that is 
the mother of all parliaments (but not the country) As in the 17th century 
institution. Bear in mind it disappeared in 1707.Do you have a problem with 
it being called British now when it has MPS from all the UK. Try watching 
the Levenson clip when he called it the English Parliament to Alex 
Salmond.All too indicative of the real problem.Too many call things that 
are or should be considered British, English and not the other way 
round.After WW2 when the Bank of England was nationalised and became the UK 
central bank why was name not eg changed to the British Central Bank or 
Bank of Britain? How often is the UK currency referred to as English pounds 
when that is not its official denomination? These are bigger and much 
important matters than some private companies that frankly I have never 
heard of being called exclusively British rather than as English.


I do think England has suffered in a loss of cultural identity. You never 
had to really stop acting it was just still all really England or it never 
really mattered to far too many acting like it was. Understandable maybe 
because you the biggest and dominant partner. We could say you made little 
attempt to try. Now you do. But you need to find a new cultural identity it 
in a positive way that can sit in a new UK arrangement. Not what is being 
offered here.


I

comments.text:
It is not to be confused with Union of England and Scotland Act 1603 or 
Treaty of Union. The Acts of Union were two Acts of Parliament: the Union 
with Scotland Act 1706 passed by the Parliament of England, and the Union 
with England Act passed in 1707 by the Parliament of Scotland.﻿

comments.text:
+Graeme Malley The Tories do hold a single Westminster Parliamentary seat 
in Scotland, one of 5 European Parliamentary seats, and over 10% of the 
members of the Scottish Parliament, so they aren't entirely wiped out. As 
for the North of England, you are right about the major cities, but they do 
have a significan number of seats elsewhere - as well as in the English 
Midlands, South West, Wales and East Anglia. If Tories had to rely entirely 
on London and the South East, they'd never be able to form a government 
(though, of course, there's not been a Tory Government since 1997). That's 
not to take the point away about Tories being generally highly disliked in 
Scotland and the North of England. 
http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/2432632/UK-General-Election-2010-political-map.html

comments.author: KTChamberlain

comments.text: +Stew182 I am glad a scottish person has stepped up to explain it better.
comments.author: Joseph Boland

comments.text:
+KTChamberlain I am Scottish and have no disdain for England or anyone who 
is English - in fact I am a quarter English and my girlfriend is English. 

What this video doesn't mention is the fact that the reason for the union 
wasn't just down to the funding of Scotland but also the bribing of the 
Scottish nobility by the already unified monarchy (who wanted its 
parliaments to join together). Again it had nothing to do with English 
people, but self-interested British monarchy and Scottish nobility. 

I did vote yes, but for political reasons - I am of the opinion that our 
Social Policy would be better run as a smaller and more social-democratic 
parliament, and that this requires independent tax raising etc. 

Some unfortunately cling to bigotry and identity - I do understand being 
proud to be Scottish but that shouldn't extent to hatred of the English (I 
have always felt British). 

It was a very long time ago yes, but the retaining of traditions, culture, 
political control over education and law etc, and even to an extent 
language has meant the feeling that Scotland should stand on its own has 
continued. The union was exactly that - a union. Scotland and England 
stayed as their own entities. The invasion of Wales and the turning it into 
a part of England has still meant their identity is somewhat less profound. 

As Joseph points out, the differing of political traditions has led to a 
conservatism being seen as an English ideal (mainly down to Thatcher I 
would say (and the same reason the North of England and Wales have disdain 
for the South East)). Also with the rightward movement of Labour, the SNP 
are now seen to represent the Social Democratic traditions of Scotland 
(which really aren't as profound or different to that many in England have 
to be honest). 

These divisions - cultural and political- have been stoked by the 
devolution of powers to Scotland, a Scottish Government who tries its best 
to exaggerate and do things differently to England, and a feeling that 
their policies have been successful. The modern approach to politics in 
Scotland has also led to some disdain towards the old-fashioned practices 
of Westminster. 

Both Scotland and England have aided and taken from one and other many 
times over the long and interesting history of Britain. To me, any hatred 
of England or the English is ignorant. If independence is really wanted, it 
should be on the basis of wanting to be self-sufficient, a feeling that it 
would benefit us, or politics based. Identity of course can play a role in 
this, but to hate people from, or to hate a country is bad. 

Importantly I will say that the majority in Scotland do not have disdain 
for England. There is also a perception that the English have disdain for 
Scotland - which I find to be widely untrue also.
comments.author: Stew182

comments.text:
the disdain for england is not what you think its more specific than that 
its for the conservative party.The conservative party is mainly an english

comments.author: simhedges

comments.text:
+jam th I'm not sure why you seem to think that England and Scotland were 
equal in size- England's always been bigger. In terms of resources, I'm 
talking about tin and copper- there's shitloads of that in the south of 
England, as well as near perfect farmland. Scotland is full of rugged hills 
and small mountains- yes, I suppose there's coal and slate up there too, 
but as you say, not worth the hassle. The whole empire, not just England, 
was giving the Romans trouble, most prominently the German barbarians. 
As to the rest of what you say, I'm not sure why you're saying it to me, I 
agree with you. That was always the case- sure, we weren't always at /war/, 
but we've never been massively friendly, even today. 
I wouldn't say that England 'earned' its gold. Earn would imply hard, 
legitimate work, not stealing from Spanish ships through funded pirates, 
but yes, England's home resources aren't really enough to build trade on- 
that was made through manufacturing, but not until later.

comments.author: Stew182

comments.text:
+jam th There are a number of reasons why it was easier for England. 
England, for one, is much larger- both in terms of land and population. 
This means more resources and labourers for the government and any private 
firms that trade by sea. England was also much better organised, as it was 
ruled by the Normans and Romans for a good amount of time- Scotland, being 
colder, more rugged and without any particularly fascinating resources, 
remained unconquered by the Romans and so was far less organised than their 
neighbours to the south. England also had an alliance with the Portuguese, 
who were another strong naval force at the time.

comments.text:
+Thomas Ellis Try the Robert Ross book a history of Scotland amongst other 
things.David negotiated his ransome dowm.He threatened new alliance with 
France.Edward III wanted to succeed him to the Scottish crown.Offered 
return of territory and some other hostages David inclined to do so but 
Parliament rejected it.Died with no heir and Robert the Steward became king 
founding the Stewart dynasty.Where was the section in CGP Greys video about 
David II? 

You have come on here and posted something which manifestly untrue. If 
Scotland was, since the end of the 100 years war, a vassal state of England 
why all the subsequent wars and battles.Why all the invasions by us 
(Flodden) Why the Auld Aliance renewed? Why the Rough Wooing.Why the desire 
by James VI to have a union rejected by English parliament.Why the need to 
discuss and negotiate union after so many hundred of years later if we 
already in homage.Its a nonsense and contradicts all the facts and writings.

You want to try and tell the world that Scotland was not an independent 
sovereign nation at the time of the union of the crowns and at the 
political and sovereign union in 1707. Why? Is your frustration that 
England had not  subjugated and incorporated Scotland as it had Wales and 
Ireland so great you have to ignore history. Do you have a need to have 
England be the all conquering bully boy of The British Isles and no room to 
recognise resistance? Scotland lost far more battles to England than vice 
versa,.and when we lost we lost big time. No rose tinted glasses here. We 
were a small backward European country.I not trying to portray us as 
anything else. But we maintained, with huge difficulty and loss of life and 
indeed suffering our ultimate independence.What are your motives to deny 
that? Yes England had huge influence.Latterly as fellow Protestant 
nation.Indeed it was English troops who helped us remove the French from 
Leith. Influence is one thing.Homage and subjugation another.You can hardly 
expect us not to take umbridge at such assertions we were actually a vassal 
state despite a myriad of contradictions from historical events.Clearly you 
are trying to get a rise.That is trolling.

You're ignorance is blinding you. I've said everything that needs to be

+Alan McEwing Fabled? Quite the contrary you uneducated fool. During the 
hundread years war Scotland allied with France meaning the English had to 
defend both sides of their land, while England was fighting the French, 
Scotland managed to successfully invade the north of England. The English 
came back to the British Isles and pushed the Scottish army back to the 
northern part of Scotland killing every man woman and child that stood in 
their way, the Scots never attacked again. When I say conquered I really 
mean that they were just subjigated by sheer brutality, Scotland became a 
mess and the kingdom that was created by Robert the Bruce was shattered in 
ruins, most of the Scottish nobles had been killed and the Scottish lords 
and the Scottish king paid homage to the English king as they all knew 
conquest was inevitable. You could say Scotland technically became a state 
of England. 400 years later the act of Union was signed. A lot happened in 
that time period but Scotland had always paid homage to the English king 
just to retain their 'independance' title. When the Europeans started 
colonising the Americas Scotland did have a chance to distance themselves 
from the English but they blew it.

comments.author: Oscem111

comments.text:
+jam th Ever heard of Offa's Dyke? That was once the boundary between 
England and Wales (You don't always need a physical boundary to seperate 
Kingdoms). Also some rulers of Wales were kings, but because of the 
separate kingdoms in Wales when they were all conquered or united the ruler 
usually had the title 'Prince of Wales' instead of 'King'. This is why the 
heir to the throne today always has the same title, because when Edward 1 
conquered Wales (thus ending it's independence) and he declared that 
England would always respect Wales' separate history and culture, so he 
carried on the tradition and said that the heir to the throne would always 
be called 'The Prince of Wales'. Sometimes the Welsh were classed as rebels 
was because of their constant rebellions and uprisings against English 
rule, this was obviously after Wales had been conquered. The Normans 
attempted to conquer Wales and they failed, they did have a small 
stronghold in the south but apart from that, Wales was separate.
comments.author: Thomas Ellis

comments.text:
+Thomas Ellis Wales wasn't you even admitted it had brief periods of 
independence but you seem to not see that the segregation between England 
and Scotland was formed due to the separation of Hadrian's wall wales was 
in England and on its side, they even saw eachother as the same, wales had 
its own province but wasn't a recognised nation, Infact they was considered 
rebels. I will also say that the modern day welsh in these times where a 
main fighting force for the English and was never treated different. Wales 
never had a king in these days kings represented a separate nation infact 
im pretty sure during the Saxon period im sure they followed the English 
king and that is pre William the conquer.
comments.author: jam th

comments.text:
+jam th Historians agree that Wales was formed after the Romans withdrew 
from Britain, there was no concept of Wales before that, you do realise 
that right? Wales was only 'considered' part of England after it was 
conquered in the 1290s, it had no autonomy over itself but it was treated 
seperatley, it was legally and politically part of England after the Laws 
in Wales act of 1535 was put into place. Before the 1290s Wales was a 
seperate country with seperate laws. It had a brief period of independence 
during the early 1400s due to the Glyndwr Rising, but that's about it. So 
saying that Wales was NEVER seperate from England is a strange thing to 
say. They fought alongside England because England controlled them, and 
they were especially useful during the battle of Agincourt. It was finally 
granted OFFICIAL country status in 1955, and has been ever since.

comments.author: jam th

comments.text:
+Oscem111 If I'm not mistaken the country that was formed by the act of 
union was called "The Kingdom of Great Britain". This included Wales and 
Ireland since both were at the time occupied by England and therefore 
consider part of it.
After the Irish rebellion in 1801 Ireland was recognised in the union and 
the country changed its name to "The United Kingdom of Great Britain and 
Ireland", with "Great Britain" meaning England and Scotland (Wales was 
still considered a part of England).
comments.author: DanielHAkerman

comments.text: +Stew182 Damm, I never even thought of that. Smart catch :)
comments.author: icecoldbite

comments.text:
+icecoldbite No, the technical term is "United Kingdom of Great Britain and 
Northern Ireland (previously Ireland as a whole)"

The Kingdom of Great Britain is the joining of Scotland and England (which 
included Wales then).

The United Kingdom did not exist until Ireland joined in 1800.

It is incorrect to say "How Scotland joined Great Britain or United 
Kingdom", because Great Britain is a geographical term) the Kingdom of 
Great Britain was formed by this event, and the United Kingdom formed 
almost 100 years later. 

Should read "How the Kingdom of Great Britain was formed" or How Scotland 
and England unified".
comments.author: Stew182

comments.text:
+Oscem111 It's the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland 

Great Britain - Scotland, England and Wales (at that point Wales was part 
of England)

United Kingdom initially - GB and Ireland

(Great)Britain/British Isles - Geographical Terms. 


It should actually be HOW THE KINGDOM OF GREAT BRITAIN WAS FORMED. 

Scotland joining with England (Wales in England) was what happened.

The Kingdom of Great Britain was the product of the union.
comments.author: Stew182

and was later adapted to the symbol of the British empire.

comments.author: bsmlvega

comments.text:
One thing left out though is that in the 1690s, the Kingdom of Scotland 
shared a monarch with the Kingdom of England. And the Scottish Parliament 
had agreed to the same succession rules as England, even when that meant 
deposing a sitting monarch as it had only a few years earlier in the 
Glorious Revolution. So it wasn't like they were antagonistic to English, 
at least not for more than 100 years, by 1690. The practical growth towards 
a union had been developing since James VI (later called James I in 
England) came south as successor to Queen Elizabeth I.﻿

+Eugene InLaw I can say 1 thing, people bitch and moan about the British 
empire, without thinking of the time period, many empires existed, not many 
nations had independence that's a fact, people also forget how the majority 
of the empire was actually gained as well, this was threw taking French and

British empire for imperialism check if you had a former ruler before 
judging. I will also say if you enjoy the fact we have overseas trade 
system set up by the British empire, the clothes you wear and the 
technology you benefit from today and use to criticise the empire are all 
the result of the Industrial revolution that changed the world of luxuries 
we take for granted took place in the British empire. Its why hong kong is 
so successful, why india is 1 of the largest economies to live, please all 
look at other colonies from other empires of the period, and tell me 
what empire has some of the most recognisable nations in the world, Canada, 
Australia, New Zealand all great places to live. and then look at south 
America owned by the Spanish and Portuguese, look up what Leopold 2nd of 
Belgium and what he did to congo.
comments.author: jam th

comments.text:
Its not that the Empire was terminated, it more fell apart, rather than opt 
out of WW2, the British Empire decided to go all in and basically sacrifice 
itself to save its European and Asian allies (Fighting the war on three 
fronts while being constantly under heavy bombing) , and eventually by the 
time the war was over the United Kingdom could no longer keep the Empire 
together especially with the creation of the UN and US intervention (UN and 
US intervention in the British Palestinian Mandate; basically the reason 
for the conflict in the area today). Today the British Empire remains 
through territories which are protected by the UK with an iron fist 
(Falklands War), a loosely connected Commonwealth, and trade and/or 
military relations with formal colonies. Like any country/empire the 
British Empire had its good and bad times, but It usually brought some form 
of democracy and stability where it went.

comments.author: Rey Narvato

comments.text:
Scotland did not join the UK she united politically with England to form 
the UK through the act and treaty of union .Ireland and Wales did not join 
the UK ,Wales had been subsumed into England centuries before and Ireland 
was an English colony .

Scotland became incredibly wealthy by fully exploiting her role in the 
British empire and by the industrial revolution of which Scotland played a 
key part, a role out of all proportion to her size .For example Scotland 
became the largest ship building nation in the world and dominated the 
financial industries through banking and insurance .The working people may 
have been poor but the country was and is not and of course the development 
of the UK did not mean that the major institutions ,church ,legal system 
.education system etc in Scotland became any less Scottish or any less 
independent as they were specifically guaranteed their independent status 
under the terms of the treaty of union .Even Scotland's parliament was not 
abolished but adjourned .﻿
